text.body:
Chapter 6.
When I found
this
so astonishing a power
placed
in
within
my
hands ,
I hesitated a long time
concerning the
use
manner in which
I should
make of
employ
it.
Although I
conceived myself capable of possessed
the capacity of bestowing
animation
yet
my to
create
^
prepare
a
creature
frame
^
for the
receiving i
reception of
t it
with all its intri
cacies of
fibres muscles
&
veins
must be
still remained
a work of inconceivable
labour
2 & 1
diffi
culty .
I doubted at first whether I should
attempt the creation of a
creature being
like
unto myself
or one of simpler
organization;
b but my imagination
was too much exalted by my first success
to permit me to doubt of my
capacity
ability to
create
give life
a
to
creature
^
being an animal
as complex
and wonderful as man.
' but
Yet
But
when I
when I
looked around for
considered
my materials
they
The materials
at present within
my command
hardly appeared adequate to so
ardous
an undertaking;
but I did not despai r.
but I doubted not that I should
ul
-timately
succeed.
I allowed that my first attempts might
be futile, my operations fail or my work
be imperfect, but I looked around on
I prepared myself
for a multitude
of
reverses,
my
operations
might
be
baffled ever
incessantly,
& at
last my work be
but imperfect,
yet, when I con
sidered
the improvement
that
which
every day
takes place in science and
mechanics
and m my attempt was so much grande r
I was encouraged to
hope
and And altho although I could not hope
that my
present
attempts would
s
at le
be in every
at least
^
lay the foundations of future
success
way perfect ' yet ' but
Nor,
could I
consider
I did not think that
the magnitude and
grandeur
complexity
of my plan
w as any argument of its impracticabi
lity.
And i I t was with these feelings
^
that
I
began the creation of a human being.
As the
smallness
minuteness
of the parts
were
formed
a
great
hindrance
to my
speed
I resolved,
contrary to my first intention, to make
him
the being
of of a gigantic stature; that
is to
say
about
7
^
seven or eight feet in
height, and proportionably large.
And
after having formed this
determination
and having spent some months in
collecting of
successfully
collecting &
arranging
my materials, I began.
No one can conceive
my the variety
of feelings which
pressed upon
me
during this time. When success raised
me
^
to enthusiasm
life and death appear
ed to me ideal bounds, which I
should first break
thro,
and pour a
torrent of light into our dark world.
A new
creation existence
would bless me as its
maker
creator
and source; many happy and
excellent
creatures
beings
natures
would owe their
existence in
being
to me.
in manner
in a manner no father could claim
the gratitude of his child
^
so completely as
I should deserve
thiers
And pur
sueing
my
these
reflections if
I
thought
that if I could bestow
life
animation
upon
upon lifeless
matter
I might in
process of time (although I now found
it impossible) renew life where
death had apparently devoted the
body to corruption.
These thoughts supported my
spirits
while I pursued my
labours
^
undertaking
with unremitting
eagerness
^
ardour .
My cheek
was
had grown
pale with study, and
pe my person
became
emaciated
by
confinement.
sometimes
on the very brink of
certainty
I
faild
yet
I still
clung to the hope which
the next day or the
nexhour next
hour might
realize.
One secret
which I alone
knew
possessed
was the hope
to which I
clung
and the moon
gazed on my midnight
labours
while
with unrelaxed & breathless
eagerness
I pursued nature to her
most secret hiding places . But
who shall
know my
^
concieve
the horrors of my secret
operatio ns
toil
as I dabbled among the unhallowed
damps of the grave, or tortured the
living
animate to ani animal to
animate
my
the
lifeless clay?
Now my limbs
now
tremble
and my eyes swim with the
rememberance,
but then a
resistless
and
all almost
frantic
^
impulse
urged me
on
forward ;
I seemed to have lost all
soul or sensation but for
one
pursuit. It was indeed
a passing
trance
that only made me feel with renew
ed acuteness
when
so soon
as
the unnatural
sti
mulus ceas ed ing
had
to operate,
and I had return
ed to my old habits. I collected bones from
Charnel houses and
with profane
fingers
meddled with the
secrets of the human
frame. In a solitary
chamberâ€“or
rather
cell
at the top of the
house
and
seperated
from all
other
appartments
by a gallery
and
staircase
I
h kept my workshop
of filthy
creation;
my
eyeballs
were
starting from their sockets in at
tending to the
minutiÃ¦
of
the my
employment. The dissecting room and
the
slaughter house
furnished many
of my
materials,
and often did my
human nature turn
from my
occupation but I whilst wal was
still urged
on by an eagerness which perpetually
encreased,
as
I brought my work
drew near
^
to
a conclusion.
The
sums Summer months
passed while I was thus
employed engaged,
heart and soul, in one pursuit. It
was a most beautiful
season:
never
did the fields bestow a more plentiful
harvest, or the vines
yeild
a more
luxuriant
vintage.
But my eyes were
s hut
insensible
to the charms of
nature
& the
same feelings which
caused
^
made
me
to
neglect the scenes around me caused
me also to forget those friends who
were so many miles
absent
and whom
I had not seen for so long a time.
I knew
that my silence disquieted
them
and I well remembered the
words of my
father.
"I know that while
"you
are pleased with
yourself
you
"will thing
think of us with
affection
"and
we shall hear regularly from
"you. And
you must pardon
me
"if
I regard
you any interruption
"in
your
corespondence,
as a proof
"that
your other
studies
duties
are equal
ly
neglected"
I
rembered knew well
therefore what
his opinion would
be
his feelings
but I could not tear my thoughts
from my
occupation
loathsome in
itself
but which had taken
a n
strong
irresistible hold of my
imagni imagination.
I
wished
as it
were
to
procr procras
tinate
^
all that related to
my feelings of
affection, untill
the great
object
of my affection was
which swallowed up every habit
of my
nature
should be
compleated.
I then thought that my father
would be
in unjust
to
if he
ascribed my
neglect to
vice
or faultiness on my
part; but I am now convinced
that
I am
^
he was
X
in the right
in co conceive
X he was
in the
right
in conceiv
ing that I
should not be
altogether free
from blame.
. A human
being in perfection ough
t
always to
preserve a
cl calm and peaceful
mind
and never to allow passion
or
^ a
transitory desire to disturb his
tranquillity. I do not think that the pursuit
of knowledge is
any
exception to this rule.
If the study to which you apply yourself
has a
d tendency to weaken your
affections
and to destroy your taste for those simple
pleasures in which no alloy can possibly
mix
then that study is certainly
unlawful
that
it is to
say on that
not befitting
to the
human mind. If this
rul rule
was
were
al
ways
observed; if no man allowed any
pursuit whatsoever to interfere with
his
tranquillity
and
his domestic
affections
Greece had
never
been
enslaved,
CÃ¦sar
would have spared his
country,
America
would have been discovered more
gradua l
ly,
and the Empires of Mexico & Peru had
not been destroyed.
But I forget that I am
moralizing
in the most
interresting
part of my
tale; and your looks remind me to
proceed.
My father made no reproach in his
letters,
an and only took notice of my
silence by
enquiring
more particularly
than before what
my
co occupations
wer were. Winter spring
and summer
passed away during my
t l abours
but
I did not watch the blossom or the
expanding leavesâ€”sights which before
had alway yeilded
me supreme
delight.
so
much
deeply was I
taken up with
engrossed in
my
occupation. The leaves of that year
were withered before my work drew
near
a
close.
And now every day
shewed
me more plainly how well I had suc
ceeded. But my enthusiasm was
checked by my
am anxiety
and I appeared
rather like one doomed by slavery
to toil in the
mines
or any other
unwholsome trade
than an artist
occupied
in
his favourite employment.
Every
nigh night
a slow fever oppressed
me
and I became
nevous
^
nervous
to a
degre
most painful degree;
a fever a dis
ease I regretted the more because I had
hitherto enjoyed excellent health &
my nerves were fi had always
boasted of my the firm ness
^
of my nerves. But
I
believed that exercise and amusement
would
soon
driv drive away
these such
sym
ptoms
and I promised myself both
of
these
when my creation should be
comple et te ed . I had had t then determined to
go to Geneva as soon as this should be
done and a in the midst of my
family find eve
